intro: Betula coriacea, commonly known as the paper birch, is a deciduous tree native to the northern regions of the Americas. It is characterized by its white, peeling bark that reveals a papery, inner layer. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters and has slender, pendulous branches. Its leaves are triangular, serrated, and turn yellow in the fall. Betula coriacea thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in boreal and temperate forest ecosystems.
